episode_title: How to Turn Data Into Dollars: The Data Shopper Story with Thomas Rudy
transcript:
ï»¿Nikolas Hulewsky (00:00.324)
I usually do like a separate intro where I take just clips from the episode and do a trailer. So, all right, Thomas, Stoke, you and I, this is a game of tag, man. We finally connected. I'm really excited about it. You are a pretty prolific entrepreneur and you're building some really cool stuff. But I think what's most interesting is the way that you've built on top of yourself. Like you took one small win to the next one, to the next one. You're just snowballing, you're compounding.


Can you talk about, guess, what was the first series of events that made you think, I can be an entrepreneur, I can do this?


Thomas Rudy (00:38.638)
We started with the very first. You wanna go back that far?


Nikolas Hulewsky (00:40.286)
Yeah, yeah, I'm curious.


Thomas Rudy (00:43.919)
The very, very first thing that I did online was I created these mystery boxes on eBay. is gonna date myself a little bit back in like 07, 08. I got into it via my brother and one of his friends. Quickly found out that that was against the platform rules. Drove a lot of sales really quickly and thought like overnight I was gonna be a massive success. So that was like the foyer into online.


Nikolas Hulewsky (01:09.822)
What? Wait, what was the what was against the rules?


Thomas Rudy (01:15.249)
Is is flagged as gambling. I mean, we're going back almost 20 years now, but basically what we would do is we would say, here's a mystery box. People would bid up to like 50 bucks on it. And in one of those mystery box, I can't remember which version of PlayStation was that at the time, but in one of those mystery boxes, there was a PlayStation and another one that was like a $5 bill or like a CD or something like that. So, you know, it's basically like rolling the dice and gambling on getting a PlayStation. Most did not, but the people that did left.


Very positive reviews. So yeah, that was like the entry of it. And then I mean, it turned into many, many things.


Nikolas Hulewsky (01:55.294)
Wait, wait, wait. I gotta ask about this mystery box stuff. How old are you?


Thomas Rudy (01:59.182)
07 I was 18 19 years old


Nikolas Hulewsky (02:02.666)
Okay, so 07-1819, you're doing these mystery boxes. How many of them did you sell?


Thomas Rudy (02:08.704)
I don't remember at the time. think like within a few hours, there was like three grand of sales, which like back then was enormous. got shut down really quick.


Nikolas Hulewsky (02:14.186)
Dude!


Was that one box though? They just bid up 3000 to one box or did they do multiple boxes?


Thomas Rudy (02:21.998)
So actually there were multiple boxes. So some of them were not selling quite like the one that kind of got us flagged. Um, like it actually worked for a little bit and it was like a modest money. Um, but yeah, I mean, there was, you know, we had listed different boxes that had different things. mean, the most prominent thing was a PlayStation. Um, I mean, even back then, like iPod touch, you know, that was like, or the one that was like, is that the one that was on your shoulder? The Nana. Yeah.


Nikolas Hulewsky (02:30.09)
Mm-hmm.


Nikolas Hulewsky (02:43.242)
man, I remember those.


Nikolas Hulewsky (02:48.01)
think that was the Nano.


Thomas Rudy (02:50.35)
I one of those.


Nikolas Hulewsky (02:53.418)
So did every box have a prize? It just depended on like the magnitude of the product.


Thomas Rudy (02:56.438)
Yeah, everybody had something. Yeah. But you know, somebody might've spent 50 bucks to get a dollar. So we got complaints. eventually got, actually, I think I looked into this recently. I feel like people are doing it again. I feel like, yeah.


Nikolas Hulewsky (03:06.29)
And did you? Okay, so you got.


Nikolas Hulewsky (03:11.444)
They are. No, there are these mystery boxes or even one thing that's really, really popular right now is cards. So people have gotten into like baseball cards and they'll buy just tons of cards because one pack might have a card that they've been looking for and they'll like go through it. They'll spend tens of thousands of dollars, but that's why I'm surprised it got banned because I feel like that's a thing now.


Thomas Rudy (03:30.414)
That's all you need.


Yeah, that's my nine year old son now. Actually, it was kind of funny. was in, I don't remember if was Cabela's or Dick's Sporting Goods and they had like a fishing mystery box. My son wanted to buy it I was like, wow, that's literally how I thought I did it when I was.


Nikolas Hulewsky (03:41.907)
No way.


Nikolas Hulewsky (03:48.362)
You were just too early.


Thomas Rudy (03:51.052)
Well, it's too early.


Nikolas Hulewsky (03:52.18)
Did you just make, okay, so you got shut down, but did you make like low five figures or did you make more than that?


Thomas Rudy (03:58.314)
I honestly don't even think we made anything. I mean, I was also doing like the retail arbitrage back then too. Like, you know, go to whatever store, look at the discount rack and sell it. had some money doing that. Actually, that's how I like paid for stuff back in the day. I really didn't have that many like jobs. think I like repped basketball. I worked at the mall for a little bit. So that was like retail.


Nikolas Hulewsky (04:10.879)
Mmm.


Thomas Rudy (04:26.144)
not Amazon, eBay arbitrage back in the day was how I like funded, you know, myself. But, you know, back then, like as a kid, like a thousand bucks a month was fine. So.


Nikolas Hulewsky (04:35.466)
So you've been a hustler, you're a hustler.


Thomas Rudy (04:39.474)
yeah, definitely like the way I've grown my career is definitely like hustle, like just go forward. Very, you know, more scrappy non-corporate as I would call it. you know, played in the corporate world too, just with the same attitude. But yeah, that was the first one. mean, that kind of got my gears turning. Wow. You can, you can make money online. You can do interesting things. You can just do whatever you want really, and just have an idea and launch it. Right. So.


Nikolas Hulewsky (04:48.97)
Scrappy.


Mm-hmm.


Nikolas Hulewsky (05:09.66)
So how did you get into from from there to like software development?


Thomas Rudy (05:15.854)
Yeah, so I mean, I was going to college. First went to Juca. I played a little basketball and I went to Central Michigan, played a smaller amount of basketball there. And really, I was going to school to be an accountant and I just couldn't do it. just could not. Just couldn't do it. I'm really glad that I didn't do it. So I honestly went to the library and would check out books on basic programming, which got me so far. And then really just kind of like...


built websites, launched websites, built websites for friends. I mean, this is before, and we're talking like mobile devices weren't really thought of back then. You were kind of building websites, not even necessarily using WordPress, just using HTML.


Nikolas Hulewsky (05:57.866)
Because mobile didn't really get popular till like 2012, 2013 was when it first, I mean, even popular is a generous term to say, but that's kind when the mobile wave started, right?


Thomas Rudy (06:09.59)
Yeah. Responsive web development wasn't a thing when I started, it was like, make sure you're accounting for Internet Explorer six or seven or whatever it was, which that was like the most brutal part of it. so yeah, mean, honestly, it just, it wasn't necessarily any aha moment or like nothing has ever really like clicked overnight, except maybe that eBay mystery box thing that, you know, like spouted off, but everything has kind of just been like a slow churn, you know, like a


Nikolas Hulewsky (06:18.429)
I'm


Thomas Rudy (06:38.862)
a long term crawl to like find success. And there's that, I mean, there's been winds along the way for sure, but that's how it started. So I really like did the basics. I was doing web development and then I got into local SEO. So I did a lot of work in local SEO earlier in my career. I guess like moving forward, know, work at Microsoft software developer, I worked at reviews.com, running tech and parts of the content.


And I think that kind of is what helped me position and like build what became my agency, which is the precursor to my business now. so yeah, I mean, it's a snapshot of really like almost 20 years now, which is kind of cool.


Nikolas Hulewsky (07:17.62)
Okay, so you've, I think it's really cool. You got a really interesting personality because most, you know, most guys in software aren't playing college basketball. I'm also glad you didn't become an accountant because I thought about it for a bit. My wife's dad's a CPA and she's like, you should be an accountant. I'm like, I blow my brains out. can't do it. But then you, so you went from accounting to software development. mean, web development.


which is interesting to me, but you built a company that you sold to Benzinga eventually, correct?


Thomas Rudy (07:55.502)
Correct, yeah, that was my agency 1020. Yep.


Nikolas Hulewsky (07:56.938)
So that was your agency. So you started this agency and what was the agency in particular?


Thomas Rudy (08:02.95)
I mean, was essentially all things performance marketing. So, I mean, a lot of the model that, you know, I learned and helped build that reviews.com with what we did there. I took and basically started servicing clients. So Benzinga, Moneyline was another one. Rocket mortgage was another one that we worked on from an SEO perspective.


Nikolas Hulewsky (08:22.772)
So I'm an idiot. What is performance marketing?


Thomas Rudy (08:26.414)
I mean, it means a lot of things to different people, but to me, it's essentially, um, you know, creating marketing that you derive revenue from based on performance. So whatever that might be, like oftentimes for us, that was SEO driven content. Sometimes it was paid arbitrage. Um, sometimes it was content syndication, distribution. Um, but generally it's like, you know, we put out a piece of marketing material, whatever that is. And then that piece of marketing material makes money, which we earn a commission on.


So Benzinga, like we, you know, we had a ton of content that was going through syndication. had a ton of content from traffic through SEO. And, you we would, you know, basically find the right partners that would meld together with that content or match with that. And. Or in a commission have whatever the payment structure is CPL, CPC, flat rate, et cetera, or a combination of all of them. Um, so the model that I employed with them was kind of an interesting one where I took virtually a negligible retainer with them.


and had performance, like an upside on it, on the performance that we built, pretty, pretty nice slug of that performance. And we built it into a, you know, seven figure month business. So it worked out very well. And I took that model and, I had other performance clients, kind like the same thing. think Benzinga was definitely one the more successful ones in that, from that strategy. and you know, we had clients that would just pay us a retainer to, right? Like they just pay us like a fee to help them, you know, like order their SEO presence or.


whatever it was, we did, did, you know, web development work too. We did paid work. Yeah. I mean, it worked out very well. Um, you know, a couple of interesting tidbits on that. think like the people at Benzinga were great, like Jason, Luke, if they were listening to this, like they were really good to us. Um, you know, that doesn't, you don't see that across all partnerships that you form, which is kind of like what I had, uh, you know, ran into a wall on.


Like you, you know, when you're having all these like performance deals and like, you know, upside is commission and you basically have, you know, 20 business partners at the same time. And it's that's like the more challenging thing to navigate.


Nikolas Hulewsky (10:31.946)
Did they buy you because you were just doing so well, making so much money, and just made more sense for them to bring you in-house?


Thomas Rudy (10:38.68)
think really what happens, they got bought by private equity. And I mean, I was


Nikolas Hulewsky (10:44.17)
How big were they, do know? Do have any idea of like?


Thomas Rudy (10:47.886)
Yeah. I mean, the, like the valuation on the purchase was 300 million. So was pretty big. And when I started, I mean, when I started working with them, I think the first year I was there was only 3 million of revenue. So it grew very quickly. mean, there was a couple really talented folks in that organization. Um, one that comes to mind is Neil Hamilton, obviously like Jason, Patrick Lane, um, Matt Cole, who I'm working with now partnered on with, with data shopper. Um, yeah, people moved really quickly and grew.


Nikolas Hulewsky (10:51.528)
Okay.


Nikolas Hulewsky (10:57.812)
Wow.


Thomas Rudy (11:17.783)
there was like a competition of the business lines and how quickly the revenue could grow and one was the affiliate revenue line.


Nikolas Hulewsky (11:23.562)
So the $300 million valuation with the PE, what was the revenue for that valuation?


Thomas Rudy (11:31.566)
think when they got bought, was floating around like 45 million a year. yeah.


Nikolas Hulewsky (11:35.469)
wow. that's geez, Louise. Three to forty five is is a time.


Thomas Rudy (11:40.462)
in like three and a half years.


Nikolas Hulewsky (11:45.524)
Did they just catch a wave or was it something special about what they were doing or was it you and your team on the marketing side?


Thomas Rudy (11:53.646)
I mean, our business line definitely had a huge portion of that. There was four other business lines that had significant revenue too. There were four different, I mean, seven figure business lines within that org, some eight figure businesses like ours was of an eight figure business at one point. I don't know what it is today, but.


Nikolas Hulewsky (12:11.434)
And just for people who don't know, sorry, Benzinga is a...


Thomas Rudy (12:15.595)
They're like, I mean, they're a financial media publisher. They're basically the way that they started was, they were like the Bloomberg for your average show, like the retail investor. And, know, gave them access to news, data sets, information, ideas, analyst ratings, et cetera, in a simpler fashion that was digestible to the retail investor, essentially.


Nikolas Hulewsky (12:42.248)
Yeah, I kind of compare them as a mix between the Motley Fool and Bloomberg. They're kind of going after the Motley Fool-esque customer, but they are a little more data heavy than the Motley Fool is.


Thomas Rudy (12:48.716)
Yeah.


Thomas Rudy (12:57.388)
Yeah, I mean, have a good, honestly, the, the biggest portion of their business for a while before I joined was their licensing business. And I don't know the current numbers, but they definitely had some really good partnerships, from a licensing perspective, you know, like distributing content to brokerages or just the raw, like financial data that they would provide to whomever. so I mean, it was an interesting business. There was really like four or five businesses inside of that org, which kind of


all took off at the same time like when I started working with them. Again, there was some.


Nikolas Hulewsky (13:28.936)
Which line were you working with in particular?


Thomas Rudy (13:31.694)
Just the, we called it the Legion department. So it was just all performance marketing, SEO paid content syndication, like whatever we could do to put a dollar in to get $2 out and hopefully $5 out. Um, that was the org that I started, headed and ran for a long time and that my org got absorbed back into.


Nikolas Hulewsky (13:50.361)
okay. So you got you got bought and then you're also working as the head of that organization in Benziga.


Thomas Rudy (13:55.93)
Yeah. Yeah. I was the head of it. Like I, it didn't exist before I started working with them. Um, you know, if I remember correctly, like month one, it's kind of funny. Month one was starting the, the Legion department. did like 40 bucks. You know, like everyone's like, Hey, I don't think it's going to work. You know, and that's kind how it always goes in this kind of stuff, you know, and like month three, we did like 60 grand and then we did like 120 grand, you know, just kind of like kept compound.


Nikolas Hulewsky (13:59.53)
Mmm.


Thomas Rudy (14:23.694)
And I mean, Benzinga was, you know, it wasn't all just me. Like there was, we had, like I brought in a good team too. And they had a great brand that was, that helped facilitate that process. But yeah, so to answer your long-winded question, like they brought our org back into the group, I think, because they just wanted to improve Revedale. And I had a solid book of business that was, you know, very complimentary to what we were already doing with them.


So it was just like an easy way to like loop us back in, basically add like another pretty substantial chunk of revenue overnight. And like I brought my team, like, you know, some of the core team members back into the org to, to run ops and all that good stuff.


Nikolas Hulewsky (15:05.844)
So as far as the way the agency function, I kind of think of the digital marketing in two buckets. One is the creative, where you're designing, thinking through what the ad's going to be, et cetera. And then there's the strategic, which is, I don't know, figuring out who you're targeting, which audience, what time of day, how much money you're throwing behind it, et cetera. Were you doing both? Were you doing the creative and the strategic?


Or am I like way off? Maybe I'm an idiot.


Thomas Rudy (15:38.062)
Yeah, no, mean, it's not the most creative endeavor, to be honest. But there's some creative aspects to it. At first, I was doing everything. I mean, even when I started, they didn't have necessarily a site, or the site wasn't structured where you could post content, track affiliate sales, do it in a fashion that's not.


you know, mind numbing and a horrible process. So I built the infrastructure for all the ads. I built like the different units that would, you know, populate and showcase. And some of those still live on today. If you, if you go on their site, there's a lot of stuff that I built that's still there. Um, so, you know, some of that was creative, but most of it was like, like from a performance marketing standpoint, like most of the work is just like functional content, testing things and seeing what works.


Now you can definitely get more creative and we did get really creative in some instances. one example is we like an NCAA bracket for, I think it was stock tickers and let people vote on it as a means to like get backlinks and have fun. And a group sponsored it too, I forgot who sponsored it, but.


There were some creative aspects to it, but at first I was doing everything and over time, you know, I just kind of like replaced myself with talent as the revenue support. So the.


Nikolas Hulewsky (16:57.802)
So you were doing stuff not only to drive traffic to the site, but also once you got traffic to the site, capturing as much information as you could about people who are visiting and then retargeting them.


Thomas Rudy (17:10.786)
Yeah, or they would just click out to the appropriate partner, right? Like somebody would come through, somebody would consume a piece of content within that content, depending on the level of intent. Like we would structure different CTAs or different offers that made sense with certain partners and, you know, hopefully monetize them, hopefully keep the partners happy with the right audience.


Nikolas Hulewsky (17:13.642)
Mmm.


Nikolas Hulewsky (17:31.31)
so this was a revenue stream also for Benzina because you had affiliate agreements that you were referring out to.


Thomas Rudy (17:38.03)
Yeah, yeah, it was 100 % of revenue stream for Benzinga and I took a cut. So Benzinga paid me, I mean, literally like a nothing retainer to do this. And I purposely, you know, I purposely wanted that because I knew that the revenue opportunity was there. So I would rather take, I mean, in retrospect, I should have taken nothing in an even higher commission. Seriously, seriously. Yeah. But so we took like a nothing retainer and by we, I mean me at the time. And.


Nikolas Hulewsky (17:41.592)
Ow.


Thomas Rudy (18:06.958)
You know, a high commission and it worked out really well. And around that I was able to hire, you know, My own set of agency talent. And, I also helped Benzinga hire, you know, like technical resources or in-house people, et cetera. So it was a very like close knit relationship, but I was, I guess I'm just, I was a vendor to them and I took that model and. You know, we'll put a lot of other groups on it. think like Benzinga was just like the most successful and the one that.


I guess I'm most open and transparent about just because it was such a good endeavor.


Nikolas Hulewsky (18:38.122)
So I was thinking you were driving traffic to Benzinga for like signups or something, right? From individuals, but you were driving traffic from the website to affiliates.


Thomas Rudy (18:49.358)
Yeah, and some of it was to sign up. they have, you know, they're, bending a pro platform. Um, you know, they have a newsletter business, they have events, um, and like they have their data licensing business too. So I, I touched pretty much every single one of those business lines in some form. Um, but the majority of it was, like working with affiliates.


Nikolas Hulewsky (19:12.554)
big does that get? So your agency you built to a seven figure a month agency, is that like a million dollars or is that like $8 million or maybe you can't tell me, but what did you guys


Thomas Rudy (19:23.926)
No, my, like the Benzinga line was over a dollars a month. I think at its peak, was touching $2 million a month. My agency will win like the mid seven figures of revenue. Cause we were taking a cut of, the, revenue from our clients and you know, our partners.


Nikolas Hulewsky (19:42.314)
Is affiliate revenue still a pretty significant part of businesses like Benzinga or has it changed at all?


Thomas Rudy (19:48.398)
Yeah. I mean, I don't know the exact numbers, but by the time I left, it was still a pretty prominent business line. Um, I mean, and really like a skeleton crew of, you know, what it used to be. So in theory, a lot higher margin. Um, you know, we were working to build it. were, you know, we spending a lot on content. We were spending a lot on resources.


Now I don't even know what the team looks like, but you know, I guess I could ask, but you know, there's probably like a few people left and the budgets are cut. So it should be very, very high margin at the moment. Um, and you know, I, I still play in some of those circles, still work with some of the partners in a different capacity now. Um, so I'll like catch wind of it, but for the most part, I'm like, it was a good, it was a good run with them. Um, great people over there. Had a lot of fun. Um,


And yeah, mean, they definitely caught some tailwind in the COVID, GameStop mania stuff that helped them out a lot too with some of that growth. But yeah, in all honesty, I still think that there's a ton more potential there. I think if you wanted to do it again, you would just kind of have to like, not necessarily tear down what's there, but the SEO tactics and the performance marketing tactics that worked in 2018.


are a little bit different now. Actually, the whole SEO landscape is a little bit different now. So yeah.


Nikolas Hulewsky (21:15.37)
What's different?


Thomas Rudy (21:18.424)
Well, I mean, the biggest thing, are you familiar with SEO at all? So I mean, the way that Google is prioritizing certain sites or ranking certain sites, especially affiliate based sites is just, you know, it's, kind of like blown up to the point where, know, in my opinion, a of people don't even know what they're doing. It's a little bit, it's a little bit of the same tactics, a little bit more of a desk work, but I think it's just ultimately like more risky to put a ton of dollars behind something like that again, because.


you've seen it time and time again, even like Forbes advisor just got knocked with a huge algo update. looks like a manual penalty. it's just riskier. You know, you can, you can build a huge business and overnight you can get wiped away. So you would have to be extremely regimented about how you're approaching that. and even still there's, there's a risk that you can get wiped out pretty quick. So, I mean, we, you know, like that was happening too, while I was working with them. So there's different ways to combat that.


Not everything from the affiliate arm was based on SEO. was, you know, content, content syndication was a huge new lever that we worked to develop. Um, obviously like paid ads, paid arbitrage found some success with their, um, but yeah, I mean, like the, the SEO, was, my opinion, it's, it's risky. Like, would you want to invest that much money or your time? And you could, there's just a risk.


Nikolas Hulewsky (22:42.568)
Well, what's interesting, you can tell me where I'm off here. This is kind of my understanding of it. You're interesting because you like this arbitrage play and you've been doing it since you were going to TJ Maxx or whatever, you know, as an 18 year old looking for retail stuff. But what I've seen, part of the biggest change in the SEO landscape is the way that Google is prioritizing things and even the Google answers where it's now like Google AI giving you an answer and you're not going to that top ranking.


website that was driving a bunch of money from affiliate links after you clicked into it to find an answer to your question. It's similar though, in the way that I view people who build social media audiences, they're building on rented land. Like if I'm on Twitter and I have a large audience or if I'm on YouTube, if they change the algorithm, all of a sudden you're not able to reach those people. So many people are taking the people who are seeing them on those platforms and getting their email addresses so that they can communicate with them directly offline. can take them off platform.


And what's interesting about that, I'm just like connecting the dots as we're talking, that is your new business. Like you are effectively in the past where I had to go to Google and pay Google or Meta to access the people who are coming and accessing their website so I can target specific people. But if, you know, if they change the way that they rank things or if they change the way they prioritize things, I get kind of Whereas your business, you're now scraping these data lists and people can come to you and target.


very specifically through email, phone number, obviously there's the opt-in lists, et cetera. it's like you're moving away from having to rely on Google and Meta to access people's attention. Is that fair? Yeah.


Thomas Rudy (24:23.118)
I mean, it's extremely fair. mean, it's part of the reason why we're doing it. I mean, I, you know, I still play very much in those performance marketing circles. Um, just love clients in those performance marketing circles. Um, and there is a nice parallel there with some of the stuff we're doing, but yeah, I mean, I honestly wanted a product that had zero reliance on an algorithm update, you know, like, you know, there's some reliance on it because ultimately are.


software works on behalf of the client's traffic. A lot of it is on page traffic though, so it's like a nice steady screen.


Nikolas Hulewsky (25:01.354)
Can you do a better job than I did of just explaining what your product is?


Thomas Rudy (25:04.814)
Yeah, absolutely. So our product is a simple piece of software. I as simple as complex as you it to be. It goes on a website. In real time, you get a feed of the users that are coming to your site and our data set allows you to return. I mean, really like a myriad of data points around that user. some of their contact information, their device IDs, their demographic data.


their financial footprint, et cetera, et cetera. So depending on the client, you can be really well equipped to help those users really seamlessly. So this group, Data Shopper, was born out of this other group, Printfineship, who was one of my long-term clients. And after I ended my tenure with Benzinga, joined up with them and...


you know, had been working with this product for a couple of years behind the scenes. so, so we do, you know, from the remarketing, do direct mail. do, you know, obviously you can pipe it to a CRM or an ad platform, and do some sort of sequencing or reaching out to them, depending on, again, depending on how the order is set up and what their business model is. and even just the, know, you're, you're not only getting, you know, Thomas Rudy and my address and my info, but


you're getting the fact that I have an iPhone and that I have the tablet and that I have a smart TV. So in one clean swoop, you can remarket all these people on every single platform, you know, really for like pennies on the dollar compared to what you're doing on Google or, or any of the platforms really.


Nikolas Hulewsky (26:40.682)
Because Google and Meta don't have that granular of information, or at least they're not willing to share it with you to be able to retarget them.


Thomas Rudy (26:47.362)
